column4: Hi, can anyone please tell me what's wrong with this nautilus script line?:              if [$filetype == "Hello"] ; then
you need space after and before []
Bizarre syntax. Are my comparisons right?
does == mean equal to? And does != mean NOT equal to?
hrm, not entirely sure about ==, it could be just = there (yes, more bizarro syntax)
== does pattern matching instead of equality test, in that case it would be the same, though

Hmm, this is bugging me. It should be very simple. I have set filetype=$(file "$arg"). All I want to do is compare the $filename with a "String" and do something if it is one thing, and do something else if it is another. I can;t find a tutorial on this anywhere.
actually, that was wrong, sorry, there's no pattern matching if the literals are quoted
So it is ==?
both = and == work, = forces strict posix compliance and turns off any bashisms
For some reason neither work
what, exactly, is the line just now?
No one in #bash is of any use. English is no one's first language, they all talk in anagrams and bash. And they sh*t on n00bs genuinely trying to learn something.
spaces, eh? you could've mentioned that...
Sorry ;)
Looks better, but still doesn't work. poningru: Yea, sure. I will do that right now.
thing is... $filetype is not "filetype: Bourne shell script text executable". it's "$arg: Bourne shell script text executable"
But if you remove the if statement and just run the gdialog is outputs "filetype: Bourne shell script text executable"
See what I mean?
well, if the name of your test file is "filetype"...
well, the file command outputs "filename: filetype"
- I get it now dude - thanks for your help
